fields.description:
Steps:
1. Connect JIRA to a database having data with V1 license. I tested with JAC data.
2. Start JIRA.

Result:
1. It give information regarding upgrade after message "You can now access JIRA through your web browser." but after that the log file is full of logs which make no sense as upgrade task has not taken place.
2. The log file is at \\filehost\scratch\6months\vbharara\JRA-18632\ 


Expected:
1. Log file should n't have any other message after giving user warning that they need to edit the license.
fields.summary: Trying to start JIRA with database(having V1 data), give user "no upgrade message" and then keep on filing log file

fields.description: The "System Dashboard" title should probably be translated given that its title cannot be changed. It used to be translated in JIRA 3.12 (not sure about JIRA 3.13). At the moment, we use the title from the database.
fields.summary: There "System Dashboard" is not translated.

fields.description: !filtergadget.png!
fields.summary: The "No matching issues found" text is butted up against the gadget chrome.

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Setup JIRA and try to restore data from an xml file having data with expired V2 license.

Result:
1. Currently we show the same message as for V1 license which is not completely right for V2.
2. There is inconsistent behavior in JIRA, while setting JIRA we allow user to put expired V2 evaluation license but if user is restoring data having V2 expired license we didn't let them restore.
3. Same behavior if try restoring data from Admin section.

Expected:
1. Proper message should be there saying Data having expired license, please put valid license.
fields.summary: Message is not proper when user try to restore data from xml having data with expired V2 license

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Login to JIRA as admin
2. Suppose user was running JIRA with evaluation license and license is expired.
3. User click on "License Details" under system.
4. User try to update the license with some expired license he/she has retained by mistake.

Result:
1. JIRA update the license without any error. We show user proper information once the license is updated but it will be great if user gets a warning message before updating.

Expected:
1. User shouldn't be allowed to update the license info with expired one.
2. I can't think of any scenario where user required to update application with expired one....please correct if I am wrong.
fields.summary: User should n't be allowed to update JIRA license with expired one

fields.description: When a gadget is configured with a certain filter, going back to the edit screen stills hows 'No Filter selected'.
fields.summary: Gadget filter picker doesn't show currently selected filter

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Setup JIRA with evaluation license.
2. Change the system date to check the expiry of evaluation license.
3. The license info dialog show status that license is expired.
4. User try creating new issue.

Result:
1. In UI front, user get a message "Your evaluation of JIRA has expired, you will not be able to create any more issues. If you are enjoying using JIRA, please consider purchasing it - http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/expiredevaluation.jsp ".
2. Log files have stack trace.

Expected:
1. No stack trace should be there.
fields.summary: Application gives stack trace if user tries to create issue with JIRA running with expired evaluation key.

fields.description: There's a few tably gadgets that don't add a horizontal scrollbar.  The ones I discoverd are the Voted and Watched gadgets.  We should check all of them.
fields.summary: Gadgets with issue tables don't add horizontal scroll bar on overflow

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-18594].
  {panel}

In Jira 3.13.5, a "ccwatcher" option was added that can add existing users whose email has been CCed on an issue as watchers.

Here in the customer's own words is their use case:

{quote}
We use Jira for our Client Services (Support) team to log issues. It
would be very useful for the team to be able to see who is cc'd on an
email. For many of our clients the people who are cc'd often do not have
an account within Jira but it would be very useful for people here to
know who is concerned by the case they are working on. We require a list
of the email addresses of those people who have been cc'd to appear on
the ticket. There is no need for accounts to be created for these people
but if this makes it easier to achieve the list we are looking for this
would not be an issue.
{quote}

Adding the ability to create accounts based on CC members that don't exist would be one way to satisfy this use case.
fields.summary: Add ability to create new user accounts for the CC list for issues created from emails

fields.description:
A JIRA issue can have multiple fix versions, it's important to have that because if an issue is reopened it is useful for developers to track the history of that issue and when the fix became available. If it has been reopened multiple times then there is even more paper trail of when the issue was resolved each time.

However, the problem we have is that when we do a search filter for resolved issues that target "released versions only", it will return any issue with a released fix version EVEN IF it also contains a non-released fix version too. This makes identifying what issues are retestable much harder as they are mixed amongst the legitimately retestable issues.

We need an option that allows the admin to dictate (probably at a project level) as to whether an issue that has multiple fix versions is deemed as "released" or not if any of those fix versions has a status of unreleased.
fields.summary: Provide an option that dictates whether an issue is deemed as "released" if it has multiple released and non-released fix versions

fields.description:
At the moment we have 2 major problems with the javascript file organisation.

Firstly we have the subproject "jira-gadgets" referencing files that are in fact inside the JIRA core project.  This needs to be improved.

Secondly we have "hand built" javascript files that get created by Scott H and then checked into svn.  This sounds error prone and should be incorporated into the build in some way.

This probably doesnt stop 4.0 shipping but it needs to be improved for the long term.

fields.description:
Scenario:
* User A retrieves issue 1 using remote API
* User B then updates description on Issue 1 using WebUI
* User A also makes changes to the description (without synchronizing the issue first) and sends the updated issue using remote API
-->
* The issue will have the description from User A
* User A will have no indication that he actually overwrote the description he never saw
* The tool (in this case Mylyn) is not able to determine this collision (without doing expensive checks before each submitting)

It would be great if the posting of an updated issue data would trigger some collision detection on the server and, if one is deteched, fail with a useful message so the tooling can present failure and solution to the user.
fields.summary: support collision detection

fields.description:
We have a subversion repository mapped into the plugin like this:
https://ourserver.us.co.uk:8443/svn/java and we want to use fisheye for web linking. However fisheye projects do not use the subversion project name as a project name. So for example our fisheye project may be 'not_unix', while the subversion repository project is called 'gnu'. So when a changeset is picked up the subversion plugin tries to link to fisheye using url:

http://ourserver.us.co.uk/fisheye/viewrep/gnu/branches/mybranch/a?r=123
 but fisheye responds that the project was not found at that location - since it is using mapped project names (the names are different to the svn repo) and would instead expect us to look in:
http://ourserver.us.co.uk/fisheye/viewrep/not_unix/branches/mybranch/a?r=123.

So - we need to be able to use the fisheye mappings for a project from subversion in the subversion plugin - i.e. either replicate the same behaviour in the svn plugin that exists for fisheye- or allow bi-directional mapping in fisheye for projects from project name or subversion project name?
fields.summary: Subversion plugin to use fisheye mappings when linking to changesets
Ability to disable smileys

fields.description:
How to reproduce:

Create in the first jira project a new issue with sub-tasks (sub-issues). Create a second project that as different issue types and sub-tasks than the first project. It is important that the issue types and workflows of the first project are _NOT_ available in the second project.

Then move the issue with sub-task to the second. You will get asked to select a new status for the issue in the second project (but not for the sub-tasks). Also fields are shown that are new in the second. Message before pressing 'MOVE':

Note: Sub-Tasks associated with this issue will lose data stored in fields not applicable in the target.

Now everything including sub-tasks are moved but they have an issue type and workflow that is not available in the second project. To get rid of this is, move sub-task to issue and back. Then the right workflows are selected.

Scanned the log file but there are no Errors / Warnings during that movement. Tried it again on test projects, then the dialog for mapping sub-tasks was shown (see Snap02). But the workflow was not selectable (see Snap01). All were default mapped to standard 'jira' workflow.
fields.summary: Moving issue with sub-task leads in target project to workflow/issue type violation

fields.description:
We now have the ability to autogenerate minified Js and CSS files.  In fact our build already does this.

We should remove the hard coded deps on the minified files in system-webresources.xml and also remove the -min files from our code base.

We should do this before 4.0 ships! :)
fields.summary: Remove minified file dependencies and ensure that the new minified JS scheme works

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

# Download [JIRA Charting Plugin 1.5-beta2|http://maven.atlassian.com/contrib/com/atlassian/jira/ext/charting/jira-charting-plugin/1.5-beta2/jira-charting-plugin-1.5-beta2.jar].
# Install it into JIRA (4.0-Beta3rc1)
# Try to generate the "Workload Pie" report.

After the last step, you will get a NullPointerException. That's because the 'descriptor' object is null when the module tries to get the 'view' HTML from it. 

If you remove all v2 plugin modules from the plugin descriptor (also marking it a _v1_ plugin) and install the plugin to WEB-INF/lib, the report will work.
fields.summary: The descriptor object of report modules in v2 plugins not initialized (null)

fields.description:
Try the following invalid query "imAFieldThatDoesNotExist in cascadeoption(p1, p2)". The error message returned will be "The field 'imAFieldThatDoesNotExist' is not supported by the function 'cascadeOption'".

I would expect the error message to be more like "Field 'imAFieldThatDoesNotExist' does not exist." which is what you get when you run "imAFieldThatDoesNotExist in (1,2)". 

It appears that the function validation is happening before we even check if the field is even valid.
fields.summary: Strange error message when using cascadeoption.
Inconsistent x-axis labels on "daily" chart (days vs weeks)

Best Regards,
Edoardo
fields.summary: JIRA 4.0 Evaluation licenses generated from MAC don't work with currently available 4.0 beta releases

fields.description:
* Run some transitions on an issue
* Open the issue
* Have a look to the tabs in the lower part of page: there is a comments tab and transitions tab. On the right side, there is an "Sort order" button / link
* Go to tab comments
* Press "Sort order" -> sorting happens
* Go to tab transitions
* Press "Sort order" -> nothing happens

The link / button "Sort order" is not intended to sort transitions, but shown for transitions.
That confuses users: they think they can order transitions.

Improvement: Show "Sort order" only when the comments tab is shown.

See also https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-42630

Uwe
fields.summary: Show the Issue Transitions "Sort order" button/link only in case the comment tab is shown

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-18545].
  {panel}

Steps:.
1. Login to JIRA.
2. Suppose user has a saved query like project =x and affectedversion =7.
3. User select the filter from manage filter and click edit, the query get open in simple navigator as that was the last selected choice.
4. User select project = y and click "View". User has ignored the "blue refresh" link unknowingly.

Result:
1. The user is now in advanced view with the query and 0 matching result.
2. If he/she tries to go to simple view, gets message query is too complex to display in simple view as there is no affectedversion =7 for project =y.
 

Expected:
1.Taken to advanced view on clicking view is confusing to user, we should handle it in simple view itself and give error message.
2. User is expecting some result when he/she clicks on view and not sifting of dialog.
fields.summary: Viewing a filter in simple navigator and changing search option, on clicking "view" takes user to advanced view

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Login to JIRA
2. BY default we have System Dashboard.

Result:
1. Under dashboard we refer to it as Dashboard.
2. In administration we refer it as "Default Dashboard".

Expected:
1. To be consistent across application we should rename "Default Dashboard" to "System Dashboard"
fields.summary: We should rename "Default Dashboard" in administration as "System Dashboard" to be consistent across product.

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Setup JIRA and create admin user.
2. Login as admin user.
3. In system dashboard we don't show project and quicklink gadget.
4. Now if user click "Default Dashboard" link in Administration.

Result:
1. User sees project and Quicklink gadget with error message "This gadget is removed by administrator.Please delete...."
2. Its going to confuse user as login user is admin only.

Expected:
1. If we don't want to show project and quicklink gadget as their is nothing to show, we can just remove those gadgets from system dashboard rather then showing some confusing message.
fields.summary: System dashboard by default has project and quicklink gadget which is not shown at the time of first login but there is error in default dashboard setting.

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Login to JIRA.
2. Suppose user has run some queries in JQL view and they are as expected there under history.
3. From manage filter or issue drop down select a filter.
4. The result shows up in view tab.
5. Click "Edit", the filter is now in JQL view.
6. Now user click on any of the previous queries from history.

Result:
1. User gets a message "Filter modified...." and all action related to modified filter.
2. But in real life, it going to be a rare occasional that any user will think of replacing query string altogether for a filter.

Expected:
1. Clicking on any query in history should reset the form and query should be treated as new.
fields.summary: Clicking any query in "history" drop down show "Filter Modified ..." message if there was a filter previously selected.

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Setup a new JIRA instance, Create admin user and login as user. By default admin gadget is their on system dashboard.
2. Try adding it on a new dashboard

Result:
1. It keep on showing the progress bar.

Expected:
1. The gadget should be working.
fields.summary: Admin gadget doesn't work when you setup JIRA

fields.description: Gadgets are ignoring the Gadget Colours in the Look and Feel configuration.
fields.summary: Gadgets are ignoring the Gadget Colours in the Look and Feel configuration.

fields.description:
steps to reproduce:

* On a repository where a certain Issue A can only be viewed for users being logged in: 
* (works best with firefox)
* login 
* navigate to issue A
* click "XML" and copy URL
* click logout 
* paste URL in address field and hit enter
* observe what is presented, clearly not XML
* (in firefox) rightclick page and select page info
* observer "text/html" as type


Downloading that file using wget and overriding the HTTP header to gzip type reveals that in fact a gz of a "not logged in" site is returned.
The type returned should match the type specified in the HTTP header...

This happens on 4.0.0 beta 2 as well as 3.13.
fields.summary: web request for XML returns a gzip but HTTP header is set to text/html
Change history of status is lacking information

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-18527].
  {panel}

High-Level Summary: Drill down capability from the top (enterprise level) to a specific issue's detail info (Fount in all Enterprise-level Project Management tools) 

Details:
I really need drill down capability starting at the highest level, and then moving deeper and deeper until I get to the lowest level of data in JIRA. An example of this is as follows:

Lansing Community College (pie chart) -> Information Technology Services (ITS)(pie chart) -> Enterprise Systems (ES) (pie chart) -> ES Projects (pie chart) -> All Issue Types for a Given ES Project (pie chart) -> All Issues for a Specific Issue Type selected (tabular) -> the bottom line data for one Issue (detail page)

The idea is that this would be a graph that would show each of these levels. For the first level (LCC), there could be such areas as ITS, HR, IER, etc. for each slice to show the different organizations that are being tracked within JIRA here at LCC. In my example, we chose the path of ITS. For ITS, there could be Server, Data Center, Enterprise Systems (ES), Help Desk, etc. each showing as a pie slice.
For this example, I chose ES. Then, the pie chart would show a slice for every ES project currently in JIRA (including Open, Re-Opened, etc.). In this example, I chose one specific project, and then another pie chart would show all Issues for that one project (a slice per Issue Type showing the number of each Issue Type in JIRA for that project). Then, you would choose one slice of the pie chart to drill down to look at a list of all of the issues being tracked for that one project for that one Issue Type. This would now show in the normal tabular format that one normally sees in JIRA. Finally, you would select a specific issue, and see the bottom line data for that one issue.

In order to do the high level filtering, we would add in custom fields to track what Org and Sub-Orgs the Issue Types are tied to, so all the data necessary to do this drill down would already be in JIRA. And, to make this work, all that really is needed is to have the ability to have the first (top level) pie chart start with a default filter. Once the user clicks on one of the slices of the pie chart, then the next pie chart would be dynamically created based on whatever slice was chosen. The query for each pie chart is identical, but the data being searched on is different based on what slice was selected. That is what would need to be "loaded" into the filter before the query was executed and the new pie chart built. This would continue down the path until you reached the existing JIRA functionality of showing the tabular results and then ultimately the detail page for the one specific issue you are reviewing.
fields.summary: Drill Down Capability - Enterprise to Issue Detail Graphical Drill Down Capability Needed

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Login to JIRA.
2. Suppose my JIRA instance has 3-4 projects.
3. Choose view all projects from the project drop down.
4. It will show me all projects with no side bars.
5. Choose 1 project and then second one.
6. The project drop down has entries for current and recent project. Again select "View all projects"

Result.
1. It still show all projects with out any side bar.
2. Just add project category in project and assign a project to it.
3. It will start showing you everything.

Expected:
1. It should show "Recent project" and "All project" tab, once user has some history.

fields.description:
{panel:title=Gadgets Replace Portlets}

Before commenting or voting, please note: Portlets have been replaced by Gadgets in versions of JIRA since 4.0 and Confluence since version 3.1, both released in 2009. This is a new but essentially incompatible technology change. Customers using recent versions of each of these products should stop using portlets altogether. If you have custom-developed portlets, it is advisable that you port this code over to the gadget technology which is a more widely supported technology based on a standard called Open Social. In the future, all Atlassian's products will support shared content in the form of gadgets as opposed to portlets. At some point in the future (not yet scheduled), portlets will no longer be supported in JIRA at all.

This issue relates specifically to the fact that versions of JIRA since 4.0 no longer use portlets to display the JIRA dashboard and as a result, the mechanism for configuring a portlet has been effectively disabled. Although there is a "legacy portlet bridge" which enables configured portlets to still be displayed, configuring new ones requires knowledge of an exact URL.

{panel}

In older versions of Confluence, he RunPortlet URL is essential to configure a Confluence's [JIRA Portlet|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/JIRA+Portlet+Macro] macro. Please see the "Obtaining the JIRA Portlet URL" section on this page:

* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/JIRA+Portlet+Macro#JIRAPortletMacro-ObtainingtheJIRAPortletURL

Currently, there is no way for users to find this URL with the advent of the legacy portlet bridge.
fields.summary: Missing RunPortlet URL in legacy portlet bridge

fields.description:
When closing a searcher, the current DelayCloseSearcher is set to null and then marked as closed. No-one should again use this searcher and it checks to make sure. There is a race condition though where another thread may get access to the searcher reference before it has been nulled and then call open after it has been closed. The following exception is thrown:

{noformat}
 java.lang.IllegalStateException: java.lang.IllegalStateException: closeWhenDone() already called
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager$1.get(DefaultIndexManager.java:86)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager$1.get(DefaultIndexManager.java:78)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.SearcherCache.retrieveIssueSearcher(SearcherCache.java:37)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager.getIssueSearcher(DefaultIndexManager.java:566)
        at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor141.invoke(Unknown Source)
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:597)
        at com.atlassian.util.profiling.object.ObjectProfiler.profiledInvoke(ObjectProfiler.java:70)
        at com.atlassian.jira.config.component.SwitchingInvocationHandler.invoke(SwitchingInvocationHandler.java:28)
        at $Proxy67.getIssueSearcher(Unknown Source)
        at com.atlassian.jira.util.searchers.ThreadLocalSearcherCache.getReader(ThreadLocalSearcherCache.java:27)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.bean.StatisticAccessorBean.searchCountMap(StatisticAccessorBean.java:214)
        ... 140 more
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: closeWhenDone() already called
        at com.atlassian.jira.util.dbc.Assertions.stateTrue(Assertions.java:145)
        at com.atlassian.jira.index.DelayCloseable$Helper.open(DelayCloseable.java:69)
        at com.atlassian.jira.index.DelayCloseSearcher.open(DelayCloseSearcher.java:44)
        at com.atlassian.jira.index.DefaultIndexEngine$SearcherReference.doGet(DefaultIndexEngine.java:208)
        at com.atlassian.jira.index.DefaultIndexEngine$SearcherReference.doGet(DefaultIndexEngine.java:179)
        at com.atlassian.jira.index.DefaultIndexEngine$ReferenceHolder.get(DefaultIndexEngine.java:296)
        at com.atlassian.jira.index.DefaultIndexEngine.getSearcher(DefaultIndexEngine.java:136)
        at com.atlassian.jira.index.DefaultManager.getSearcher(DefaultManager.java:39)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIssueIndexer.getIssueSearcher(DefaultIssueIndexer.java:185)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager$1.get(DefaultIndexManager.java:82)
{noformat}

There should be a mechanism to detect this and retry.
fields.summary: Race condition when closing a DelayCloseSearcher

fields.description:
If a plugin has two components, one of which has an injection dependency on the other. If the injected component is disabled from the JIRA plugin admin screen, JIRA will not start. 

The only way to get the plugin to work with JIRA again is to manually remove the disabled database entry for the injected component.

I reproduced this in both 3.13.4 and 4.0 trunk. There are support cases due this issue occuring with the Fisheye plugin.

I have attached a dead simple plugin that can be used to reproduce the problem. The plugin contains two components, TestDependent and TestDependency. TestDependent has TestDependency as a constructor argument (and is hence has an injection dependency on TestDependency). 
# Install the plugin, start JIRA
# Browse to the plugin admin screen and disable the TestDependency module. 
# Restart JIRA.

Note that in 3.13 exceptions are thrown by the pico intializer and JIRA does not start, in 4.0 JIRA is locked. Neither case allows the user to re-enable the module via the interface and fix the problem, effectively forever breaking the plugin install until the disabled status of the component is manually removed from the database.
fields.summary: Disabled JIRA plugin components can cause JIRA to not start
